pages.caption: The image is a black and white photograph of a man seated at a guitar, holding it with both hands. He is wearing a dark-colored t-shirt and appears to be focused on playing. The photograph is taken from a slightly elevated angle, providing a view of the man and his instrument. The background is a simple, light-colored wall. The text on the image provides a detailed account of the musician's life and career, including his early musical inspirations, his time with the Mediators, his performances with Jerry Corbett, and his solo career. It also mentions his album "American Pie" and his album "Top Nine", along with his album "Buddy Hollyy's Everyday". The text also notes that he was a member of the band The MCs and that he performed with Jim Crace and Ivana Vollanova.
pages.text_content:
Meet the Artist
Born in New Rochelle, New York on October 2, 1945, Don McLean grew up with such wide-ranging musical inspirations as Buddy Holly, Frank Sinatra, and performed on numerous stages where he was part of the folk scene that included his friend Jim Croce and Ionova University. He graduated from the John McLane School of Music and was a member of the John McLane Quartet. Don McLane's first concert in 1970 with Jerry Corbett of the Youngbloods fame (producing his first album in 1969) was followed by a year of touring with the Carole record companies. When it finally came out, the label released a year before the recording of the 1970s album. The label garnered excellent reviews and established McClane as a club headliner. He also performed thirty concerts with the peep Seeger, launching the costs of a club in Bristol, Maine, performing concerts with the peep Seeger, and in late 1971 he released American Pie on United Artists. He became the most successful new artist to break the sound at the end of the year. The impact of his music was analyzed by "Time, The Record and Newsweek" as a mere single, radio and television media event that reached beyond life. The impact of his music was also analyzed by "World Record" and was named a Merit Album for Grammy Awards (Best Album, Best Record, Best Performance, Almost as Good as the American Pie). He was also an artist of the year that year. Vincent "Vincy" McLean (born Frank Don McLean) took a break from concert and performed to play in play-by-play settings, an album of non-giggers, with mandolinist Frank Kelly, country, and bluesy originals. Some of his club originals recorded in traditional re-lonelier style were recorded as "Mountain of Mourair" hit by the LP. He became a number-one country hit in Ireland, where McLean is still a superstar.
McLean took a break from concert and performed to play in play-by-play settings, an album of non-giggers, with mandolinist Frank Kelly, country, and bluesy originals. pages.caption: The image is a black and white photograph of a man seated at a piano, with his hands resting on the keys. The photograph is titled "Did You Know..." and is part of a series of photographs that explore the life and career of Don McLean. The text accompanying the photograph provides a detailed account of McLean's life, including his accomplishments as a Western horseman, his involvement in the film industry, and his contributions to the music industry. The text also mentions his involvement in the documentary film "Tomorrow" and his role in the BBC TV specials. The photograph is taken from a slightly elevated angle, offering a comprehensive view of the man and his surroundings. The background of the photograph is a plain white surface.

The image is a page from a book or magazine, featuring a list of Don McLean's songs and albums, including "Everyday", "Midnight Special", "American Pie", "When Love Begins", "The Pattern is Broken", "Victor", "Babylon", "Crying", and "Chain Lightning". The page is divided into two columns, with the left column listing the songs and the right column listing the albums. The text is in English and includes information about the songs' popularity and distribution. The page also includes a brief biography of Don McLean, including his background and career.
pages.text_content:
...that Don McLane had a Top 10 hit in Monaural of "Everyday" (The Buddy Holly Classic) in England. ...

...that Don McLane appeared on the first "Midnight Special" in 1974, and was a guest on the Mike Douglas and Merr Griffin shows as well as night special "Great American Dream" before he released a hit. ...

...that Robert Flack's "Killing Me Softly With His Song" was written by Lori Lieberman and Charles Gimble and Norman Fox after Lori heard a McLane show at Los Angeles Troubadour. ...

...that "American Pie" was featured in the award-winning Broadway show "Kennedy's Children" in 1973, and the film "Who Killed Me Softly, a Song about Don" beat out Perry Como's version of "I Love You" a year later by 1971. ...

...that on New Year's Eve of 1971, American Pie was the top song of the year on New York's WABC, and a year later it was number two. ...

...that McLane's "Casteries In The Air" charted twice, first as his debut single from the tapestry album, and later as a B-list charted twice. ...

...that Don McLane created two songs "When Love Begins" and "The Pattern is Broken" for the feature film "Fraternity Row", produced and acted by USC students which received rave reviews. ...

...that the feature film "Fraternity Row" voted a Top 10 by the Los Angeles Critics Association. ...

...that "Vincent" was an even greater international hit than "American Pie", earning gold records in England, Australia, Holland, Italy, Brazil, Belgium, New Zealand and other countries. ...

...that the original Life Magazine's final issue featured only one music article — an update on Don McLane. ...

...that the original Life Magazine's final issue featured only one music article — an update on Don McLane. ...

...that the album hit the top of all industry conventions when the over eight-minute single "American Pie" defied all three trade charts by the start of 1979. ...

...that the album hit the top of all industry conventions when the over eight-minute single "Vincent" was used by Leonard Nimoy in his 1979 Jane-Man theatrical presentation of the same name. ...

...that "V
